Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Project: Expanding the use of Remotely Operable Research Instrumentation in the Classroom to Transform Undergraduate Geoscience Education

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This collaborative project is examining the remote operation of analytical instruments, specifically a scanning-electron microscope and electron microprobe analyzer housed at Florida International University (FIU), to facilitate inquiry-based approaches to learning in undergraduate geoscience courses. The effectiveness of remote instrument use is being assessed across different course levels and audiences at four diverse institutions: FIU, Valencia Community College, Florida Gulf Coast University, and the University of South Florida. Faculty at each institution are adapting instrument use to their courses and students, and using common methods to assess learning gains and changes in students' attitudes along a novice-to-expert trajectory. Instrument use and learning assessment at the four partnering institutions is being supplemented by national-level outreach to engage further partners, using hands-on workshops and follow-on individual training and consultation for faculty who commit to pilot use in their own courses.

The intellectual merit of the project lies in its well-formulated plan to leverage fixed-location, high-end analytical instruments to enable authentic research and inquiry within the undergraduate curriculum at remote institutions. The embedded educational research addresses important questions of a) how much and what type(s) of remote instrument-aided inquiry enable targeted student-learning outcomes, b) what factors determine effectiveness as institution type, curricular level, and student audiences vary, and c) what challenges exist for widespread propagation of the approach and how might these be overcome. Broader impacts of the project include a) the production of insights and practices that promote remote use of research-grade analytical instrumentation at multiple levels of the undergraduate curriculum, providing a model that could be used at other research centers to enable heretofore inaccessible analytical capabilities at a wide range of undergraduate institutions, b) engagement of a diverse range of students (from seniors in majors' classes to first-year non-majors in introductory classes) and institutions (from research universities to community colleges) in authentic research, a high-impact practice for retaining students in STEM disciplines, and c) professional development for faculty at the partnering institutions and beyond, as well as for a postdoctoral scholar and graduate student engaged in discipline-based educational research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Participant Involvement: The Valencia College (a 2-year college) portion of the project was developed as a semester long sands project, using a place-based approach to inquiry. Over the course of the project, 435 students remotely operated the scanning electron microscope (SEM) at the Florida Center for Analytical Electron Microscopy (FCAEM). Of these 435 students, 305 students also operated an electron dispersive spectroscope (EDS). 4 of these students worked on volunteer projects during the summers of 2017 and 2018, preparing sands and preparing EDS spectra and 3 students attended the 2018 Florida Undergraduate Research Conference. This project also provided positions for 2 FIU post-doctoral fellow working with FCAEM on education and outreach activities, one of whom was hired by Valencia College as an earth science tenure-track professor. 49 faculty members attended two workshops conducted at Valencia College in 2016 on inquiry-based learning and included hands-on demonstrations for faculty/student use of the SEM in classroom.

Products: 15 sands from various global locations and a sand from Valencia College (collected by students) representing a variety of global tectonic and environmental settings are included in the sands repository available for general use at FCAEM. All 15 global sands have been cleaned and sieved and are suitable for elemental evaluation with the EDS. In addition, 10 sands have been sorted to include only quartz grains for evaluation of surface micro-textures using the SEM. 16 sands are also available as Gigapan images through the GEODE and the Gigapan websites and can be used in the absence of access to reflective microscopes in the classroom. FCAEM also has 9 Ocean Drilling Project (ODP) samples of quartz grains for micro-texture evaluation. This part of the project was developed in conjunction with the MSI-REaCH project. Curriculum materials for use with the 16 sands and the ODP samples are available on the 2017 Earth Educator’s Rendezvous website. EDS spectra (24 grains) of 9 of the sands will be available for general use in summer of 2019 on the GEODE website and can be used with the Gigapan images to evaluate sands when SEM/EDS time is not possible. 

Pre- and post- learning assessments and pre- and post-attitude surveys were developed for Valencia College by modifying the assessments used at USF in the Phase 1 CCLI project for a 2-year college population. The most significant improvement in student understanding concerned students’ evaluation of quartz sand microtextures (SEM work) and their ability to relate these to depositional environments. Students had more difficulty in the making connections between sand compositions (EDS work) and provenance.  Overall, the use of the SEM had a positive impact on the students’ experiences. In general, use of the SEM in the introductory earth science classroom helped facilitate learning of science, increased confidence in understanding of science from data collection and interpretation, evoked a positive response to working in groups, and motivated some students to take further science courses.

Dissemination: Talks on this project were presented at 2017 NC-NE Geological Society of America (GSA) meeting and at the 2017 Earth Educator's Rendezvous (EER), which included a teaching demonstration. Posters were presented at the 2017 GSA national meeting and at the 2018 EER meeting. The PIs hosted demonstration tables at numerous regional conferences, providing hands-on individual sessions with the SEM/EDS and EPMA instruments. These meetings where demos were offered included: 2015 and 2016 SE GSA, 2016 SC GSA, 2017 cordilleran and NE-NC GSA, and 2016 CUR biennial meeting.
